channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: News: Latest Updates From Deadly Shooting at Paris Newspaper
item.description: New York Times reporters are providing live updates from the deadly shooting at a satirical newspaper in Paris.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A woman held up a placard that translates to "I am Charlie" as she and others gathered at the Place de la Republique in Paris.

item.title: Charlie Hebdo Editor Made Provocation His Mission
item.description: Stéphane Charbonnier, the editor of a French satirical magazine who was killed in an attack on the magazine’s offices Wednesday, was instrumental in a series of defiant campaigns.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Stéphane Charbonnier, the editorial director of the satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo, spoke to reporters in Paris in 2012.

item.title: Terror Attack on Charlie Hebdo Newspaper in Paris Kills 12
item.description: A number of prominent editors and cartoonists at the satirical newspaper, which was firebombed in 2011, and two police officers were said to be among those killed.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, the cartoonists Jean Cabut, known as Cabu; Bernard Verlhac, who drew under the name Tingous; Georges Wolinski; and Stéphane Charbonnier, better known as Charb.

item.title: Letter From India: India Finds Domestic Tourism Isn't Always a Good Thing
item.description: In many places, foreign tourism is down, only to be replaced by the "cheap domestic tourist."
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: German Government Websites Shut Down, and Ukraine Group Claims Responsibility
item.description: The group claiming responsibility for the apparent cyberattack criticized German support for the “criminal government” in Kiev, which is waging war against against pro-Russian separatists.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Eurozone Consumer Prices Fall for First Time Since 2009, Adding to Deflation Fears
item.description: The decline put pressure on the European Central Bank to prevent a downward price spiral that could further damage the banking sector.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and JACK EWING
item.media:description: An electronics store in Athens. Deflation can cause consumers to delay purchases, as they await prices to fall further.

item.title: Tail of Missing AirAsia Plane Is Found, Indonesian Official Says
item.description: The development announced Wednesday could be significant because Flight 8501’s so-called black boxes were contained in the tail.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MCCAWLEY
item.media:description: A series of photos taken by divers working in the Java Sea showing what is believed to be wreckage of AirAsia Flight 8501. The images were released by Indonesia’s National Search and Rescue Agency on Wednesday.

item.title: At War Blog: A Young Private, Killed in World War II, Still Leaps off the Page
item.description: Pvt. Richard Halvey’s death in North Africa in 1943 was a loss his family never got over, but his great-niece, Kiley Bense, has sought to get to know him through both family stories and a scrapbook containing some ephemera of his short life, including his letters home.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By KILEY BENSE
item.media:description: Private Richard Halvey in an undated photo.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Strives to Be on African Minds, and TV Sets
item.description: While China imposes strict controls on foreign-produced entertainment at home, it is eager to see its own cultural products embraced abroad. And in Africa, Chinese television shows have become immensely popular — at least according to the Chinese state news media.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:credit: Sven Torfinn for The New York Times
item.media:description: The state-run China Central Television opened CCTV Africa in Nairobi, Kenya, in 2012.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Propaganda Icon Loses a Layer of Myth
item.description: The origin of a tale about cadets at the United States Military Academy at West Point learning about the notorious soldier Lei Feng has been revealed.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A visitor posing in front of images of Lei Feng at a Beijing exhibition in 2013 marking the 50th anniversary of "Learn from Lei Feng Day."

item.title: Former Korean Air Executive Indicted Over ‘Nut Rage’ Incident
item.description: The executive, who was angry about the way she was served nuts, was charged with violating aviation safety regulations and conspiring to hush up the affair.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Extremist Group Claims Responsibility for Suicide Attack in Istanbul
item.description: The Revolutionary People’s Liberation Party-Front identified a female bomber who killed herself and a police officer in a popular tourist area.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Car Bomb Kills Dozens of Applicants at Police Academy in Yemen
item.description: An Interior Ministry official said that at least 31 people were killed and that more than 70 were wounded in Sana, the capital.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Palestinian Gets 3 Life Sentences in Killing of Israeli Teenagers
item.description: A court imposed the maximum penalty on a man described as logistics commander in the abduction of Eyal Yifrach, Gilad Shaar and Naftali Fraenkel.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Hussam Qawasmeh, center, shook hands with his lawyer after his sentencing Tuesday.

item.title: Tail of Crashed AirAsia Plane Discovered in Java Sea
item.description: Divers and an unmanned underwater vehicle on Wednesday spotted the tail of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea with 162 people on board, an important finding because the jet's all-important black boxes are located in that part of the aircraft.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Paraguay: Officials Yield on Protest
item.description: The government agreed Tuesday to meet this month with former workers who have nailed themselves to crosses over a wage dispute.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: On the Open Road, Signs of a Changing Cuba
item.description: A road trip across the island revealed a slowly changing Cuba — beautiful, tired and looking ahead.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Julio César López checked his Fairlane.

item.title: Egyptian Leader Visits Coptic Christmas Eve Service
item.description: The state news media declared President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi the first Egyptian president to attend such a service.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS

item.title: World Briefing:: Russia: Navalny Defies Orders
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, said Tuesday that he had defied his house arrest by walking to his local store to buy milk.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Has Made ‘Significant’ Advances in Nuclear Arms Program, South Says
item.description: According to a Defense Ministry white paper, North Korea appears to have made progress toward making a nuclear warhead small enough to fit onto a missile capable of reaching the West Coast.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
